Arms being resold to foreign terrorist organizations

The glut of surplus WWII arms has created quite a lucrative market for black market arms dealers who are willing to sell to the world’s more unsavory elements. The worldwide abundance of surplus firearms means that prices are low and demand is high wherever armed conflict rages. Our internal security has just uncovered an illicit arms trafficking ring operating out of our country, but has not made any moves against it yet. We are reasonably sure that the smugglers are supplying arms to various terrorist organizations. How shall we proceed?
None of our business
Organize an inquiry
We must put a stop to this immediately

Arms contracts linked to humanitarian aid

The glut of surplus WWII arms has created quite a lucrative market for black market arms dealers who are willing to sell to the world’s more unsavory elements. The worldwide abundance of surplus firearms means that prices are low and demand is high wherever armed conflict rages. Our internal security has just uncovered an illicit arms trafficking ring operating out of our country, operating under the cover of humanitarian aid to a nation we are embargoing. How shall we proceed?
Cover up the affair
Organize an inquiry
We must put a stop to this immediately
Arms sales inquiry absolves government of blame

The recent inquiry into the criminal arms sales emanating from our country has found that our government had absolutely nothing to do with them, and that all smuggling operations were apparently the work of independent bad actors. Naturally, we have condemned these unlawful acts.
Excellent news
Arms sales inquiry ends inconclusively

The recent inquiry into the criminal arms sales emanating from our country has been unable to find any evidence linking our government to the smuggling operation, but neither has it found evidence to exonerate us. Lots of questions remain unanswered, but fortunately for us the situation is murky enough for us to enjoy full deniability.
Could have been worse
Arms sales inquiry lays blame directly on government

The recent inquiry into the criminal arms sales emanating from our country has traced the money trail directly back to our government – we’ve been caught red-handed handing weapons over to international terrorists. We might still be able to bottle this up, but there are no guarantees. What shall we do?
Cover the result up
Let it be released
Arms sales inquiry lays blame on high-ranking minister

The recent inquiry into the criminal arms sales emanating from our country has traced the money trail directly back to a very high-ranking minister in our government. This will severely damage our public image if the report gets out. We might still be able to bottle it up, but there are no guarantees. What shall we do?
Cover the result up
Sack the minister
